content_html: @stargazer Ka aroha, I've had similar experiences too, I don't call myself a "Kiwi" anymore.

And as this cycle goes on and more auto-generated "content" gets put on the web, it gets harder and harder for actual writers and artists to have their creations found.

So then the urge arises to share it with online communities where the folks who've been interested in your stuff in the past can be found. Most of those are not actually on the open web, so the search results on the open web get less and less original and less and less human.

It's an anti-renaissance.

The way to offset this is to share with individuals, to share in person.

The part of me that believed in the potential of the open web, that took such joy in random connections weaving me together with humans around the world, is losing hope. It makes me so sad to lose that.

I get a little bit of in Mastodon, yes, but what Mastodon doesn't have is a place for my creations that can be found again and again. What if my profile was my website? Perhaps there's something in that idea.

In any case, my thread yesterday on the impending #economic #polycrisis kind of blew up. I think it hit a nerve and a lot of people feel like I do. The sense, not only of impending doom, but also, "Let's just get the fucking doom over with already."

And, if you haven't read Cory's piece on that, here it is.

> The real (economic) AI apocalypse is nigh. https://pluralistic.net/2025/09/27/econopocalypse/#subprime-intelligence

Only the thing is? This doom could be bad. Like really bad.

[contd]

Back in the late '90s I had all my 401K money in high-growth funds. It made sense at the time, everything was go go go.

And then 2001 happened and I ended up with less in those funds than I had put in.

Now, investment mangers told me the same thing they'll tell you: over the long run high-growth funds always earn more. Well, for me it took a 'long run' of eight years ‚Äì including new contributions ‚Äì before those funds recovered. So I got sick of it and moved the money to safe havens.

[contd]

For once I did the right thing, because when the subprime mortgage crisis hit I wasn't affected at all. In fact my money in bond funds did better than before.

I say all this to point out most of you are gonna get hurt really bad when that AI bubble bursts. Even my 'safe' investments could be affected. And if we get the economic polycrisis I've been writing about?

We might see a complete economic collapse for a while. You know, most investments wiped out. People going hungry.

[contd]

And that's a really dangerous place to be when you have a demagogue in the White House. Because desperate people are willing to try ANYTHING. And the USA still has the biggest and most powerful military in the world.

And I'll bet you didn't think I'd be ending this thread in this way when you started reading it. Did you?

Try this. Open a note and paste a perfect example of what you need. Something like a project update or a client bio. Then write a prompt that says: ‚ÄúUse the exact same structure and headings as the example below. Now write a new one about [your topic].‚Äù See what happens.

Stop accepting messy outputs. Show the AI the blueprint.

#AI #ArtificialIntelligence #NeuralNetworks #MythBuster #FactCheck #Debunked #PromptEngineering #AIPrompts #TechEducation #DigitalLiteracy (2/2)

Another insight: There is no reason anymore to not have tests. Not even for trivial or temporary things, or when heavily time limited. Just let the AI write _something_, so you have at least _something_ that might fail when things break. It's in any case better than having nothing. #AI #VibeCoding

Getting very good results from #JetBrains #Junie (which seems to be much faster on a Sunday) by writing prompts as I would write issue descriptions / suggestions / review comments for my team. With the main difference that the lag between iterations is down from hours / days to mere seconds. O_O

Certainly won't replace a junior dev, but it changes what a junior dev has to do to be actually useful. Execution alone isn't enough; AI agents are already pretty good at that. #AI #VibeCoding

@neo As someone who works (at least partially) in professional software testing: A bad test might be worse than a non-existing test because of the false confidence a bad test can give you if it is still green even tough it should be broken.

In contrast: a missing test case should show up in coverage metrics or when checking that every requirement has a test so you know you still got work to do.

@considermiranda @pluralistic Few serious AI researchers claim the AGI around the corner.

Now, especially US senior businessmen, with the oily behaviour of experienced snake oil salesmen, have been talking about the wonders and dangers of AI for the past years. Some of them, one has the feeling, manage to do so without taking a break to breathe.

I just had a ‚Äúcheer session‚Äù for AI in my company, and I realized afterwards that the ‚Äúvisiting dignitary and cheerleader‚Äù giving the speech was actually a CEO of an HR firm, and visiting professor with an MBA. So American.

Not a Mathematician, Statistician, Data Scientist, Professor of AI (yes there are these, old school and ML style nowadays) to tell us that we have to endorse AI or become obsolete, but an HR guy with an MBA.

Funny thing is, if I ask my AI research buddy to list me 6 serious "real" AI researchers (maths, CS, eng background, no humanities or MBAs preaching without understanding the reality) that argue that AGI is around the corner (less than 10 years), and we chat about the results. I make it remove the two non-hard science examples in the first round, and then I make it remove all scientists that work for companies that have a commercial interest in AI directly or indirectly.

And all the researchers that have relevant grants from companies directly or indirectly that have commercial interest in AI. Oops, all 6 names from the USA suddenly dropped from the list. Isn't research for pay great. Next list has suddenly EU/EEA/CH researchers, and it has to admit that the prognosis for AGI from European researcher that get untainted government funds are way less optimistic. More like, yes, the horizon has moved up significantly. Perhaps AGI this century. 50 years.

Interesting detail too, for most of the pro-AI European researchers it had no nice sounding sound bites, but for US researchers with commercial interests (and that's it also seems US researchers at universities) having some phrases on your lips that come directly from the PR department is normal.
@jwcph @pluralistic Gee, I wonder so about the reasons for the mysterious productivity slowdown.

@phonner Nice writeup!

Your coding example seems to work because mathematics is the main character of the show and coding is a supporting cast member. Therefore it's ok to use LLMs for coding support.

The mathematical observation example doesn't work for the same reason--the mathematics is the focus and outsourcing it undermines student learning outcomes.

From your perspective as a math teacher this makes perfect sense. But a computer science instructor might make math the supporting character and coding the focus, and therefore encourage LLM support in explaining mathematics. I've seen this in my own courses, and it subjects students to a lot of whiplash. They are able to identify appropriate uses of LLMs within a course, but outside of the course or across a curriculum there's a lot of mixed messaging.

@rbassett It's an interesting point about the context dependence of "appropriate use". And I think it is the mixed messaging that is the major problem, not necessarily the students' ability to adapt to these different scenarios. It's new terrain for many, so it will take some time for old school and new school to sort it all out I suppose.
@rbassett And I wish I could my Wordpress / Mastodon integration working. I'd love for comments like this to live on the blog!
@phonner @rbassett I wonder if there's a Mastodon extension that shows threads as comments - I bet ChatGPT could help you set it up if there were!
@dneary @rbassett There is an ActivityPub plugin for Wordpress, but unfortunately my hosting service blocks the necessary back-and-forth.

@phonner there was just a professor who was writing that he found a correlation between weaker performance in his course overall and use of AI. That's my general thinking that it has potential to hinder developing thinking and writing skills

@benleis I'm sure there's some truth in this. But I'd be skeptical of any professor's claim that a measurable negative correlation between AI and "course performance" (whatever that means, and of course it is almost certainly very subjective) has been measured or observed. There's also a lot of "Kids these days" going around, now and always. The same things have been said about calculators and spell check (and pencils!).

@phonner Nice! I really liked your conclusion: "don't let AI do your thinking for you" is a wonderful summary. Lately, I have been using AI to help debug issues where something isn't working as I expect, or I got issues b/c a tutorial is written for Ubuntu and I'm using Fedora or CentOS.

I've found LLMs to be wonderful pair programmers for debugging problems. "Your compose.yml looks good - let's try to reach the Internet from inside a container with 'docker exec $CONTAINER ping 8.8.8.8'" - but I also try to understand what commands it's asking me to run and how to interpret outputs, and LLMs can help with that too.

@phonner
"some can‚Äôt remember how a for loop works" - I once had a student who didn't even understand how loops work to begin with, or variables! Despite 3 meetings about this, some including her parents (her first program was plagiarised), they still kept using 30 variables sequentially instead of using 1 variable in a loop, and this was in Computer Science, not Maths!

"Recent advances in text-to-video (T2V) generation have enabled the creation of high-fidelity, temporally coherent clips from natural language prompts. Yet these systems come with significant computational costs, and their energy demands remain poorly understood. In this paper, we present a systematic study of the latency and energy consumption of state-of-the-art open-source T2V models. We first develop a compute-bound analytical model that predicts scaling laws with respect to spatial resolution, temporal length, and denoising steps. We then validate these predictions through fine-grained experiments on WAN2.1-T2V, showing quadratic growth with spatial and temporal dimensions, and linear scaling with the number of denoising steps. Finally, we extend our analysis to six diverse T2V models, comparing their runtime and energy profiles under default settings. Our results provide both a benchmark reference and practical insights for designing and
deploying more sustainable generative video systems."

I went to an AI training this morning, and they were showing us how to generate an image on Gemini. One of the prompts was a Fijian man, and I found it interesting that it put up a picture of an Indigenous Fijian man, and didn't choose a Fijian Indian.
Made me think about the time I was in Turkey, on a tour with a bunch of Australians. One of them asked me where I was from, and I said I was a Kiwi. He said that I don't look like a New Zealander. Any of you of you who know me can guess my response - no, I didn't swear. Just said that this was what we look like now, so he better get used to it.
I remembered this because I know that when the prompt for a New Zealander is put in to generate an image, it won't bring up a picture of someone like me.
That realisation hit me, unexpectedly, with some feelings.

Cory Doctorow @pluralistic on #AI:

[T]he AI bubble is driven by monopolists who've conquered their markets and have no more growth potential, who are desperate to convince investors that they can continue to grow by moving into some other sector, e.g. "pivot to video," crypto, blockchain, NFTs, AI, and now "super-intelligence." Further: the topline growth that AI companies are selling comes from replacing most workers with AI, and re-tasking the surviving workers as AI babysitters ("humans in the loop"), which won't work. Finally: AI cannot do your job, but an AI salesman can 100% convince your boss to fire you and replace you with an AI that can't do your job, and when the bubble bursts, the money-hemorrhaging "foundation models" will be shut off and we'll lose the AI that can't do your job, and you will be long gone, retrained or retired or "discouraged" and out of the labor market, and no one will do your job. AI is the asbestos we are shoveling into the walls of our society and our descendants will be digging it out for generations:

https://pluralistic.net/2025/05/27/rancid-vibe-coding/#class-war

The only thing [‚Ä¶] that we can do about this is to puncture the AI bubble as soon as possible, to halt this before it progresses any further and to head off the accumulation of social and economic debt. To do that, we have to take aim at the material basis for the AI bubble (creating a growth story by claiming that defective AI can do your job).

People Are More Likely to Cheat When They Use AI | Scientific American

September 28, 2025, 4 min read

People Are More Likely to Cheat When They Use AI

Participants in a new study were more likely to cheat when delegating to AI‚Äîespecially if they could encourage machines to break rules without explicitly asking for it

By Rachel Nuwer edited by Allison Parshall

Mark Airs / Science Source

Despite what watching the news might suggest, most people are averse to dishonest behavior. Yet studies have shown that when people delegate a task to others, the diffusion of responsibility can make the delegator feel less guilty about any resulting unethical behavior.

New research involving thousands of participants now suggests that when artificial intelligence is added to the mix, people‚Äôs morals may loosen even more. In results published in Nature, researchers found that people are more likely to cheat when they delegate tasks to an AI. ‚ÄúThe degree of cheating can be enormous,‚Äù says study co-author Zoe Rahwan, a researcher in behavioral science at the Max Planck Institute for Human Development in Berlin.

Participants were especially likely to cheat when they were able to issue instructions that did not explicitly ask the AI to engage in dishonest behavior but rather suggested it do so through the goals they set, Rahwan adds‚Äîsimilar to how people issue instructions to AI in the real world.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs becoming more and more common to just tell AI, ‚ÄòHey, execute this task for me,‚Äô‚Äù says co-lead author Nils K√∂bis, who studies unethical behavior, social norms and AI at the University of Duisburg-Essen in Germany. The risk, he says, is that people could start using AI ‚Äúto do dirty tasks on [their] behalf.‚Äù

K√∂bis, Rahwan and their colleagues recruited thousands of participants to take part in 13 experiments using several AI algorithms: simple models the researchers created and four commercially available large language models (LLMs), including GPT-4o and Claude. Some experiments involved a classic exercise in which participants were instructed to roll a die and report the results. Their winnings corresponded to the numbers they reported‚Äîpresenting an opportunity to cheat. The other experiments used a tax evasion game that incentivized participants to misreport their earnings to get a bigger payout. These exercises were intended to get ‚Äúto the core of many ethical dilemmas,‚Äù K√∂bis says. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre facing a temptation to break a rule for profit.‚Äù

Participants completed these tasks with varying degrees of AI involvement, such as reporting the numbers directly themselves, giving the AI rules about what numbers to report, giving it biased or unbiased training data or providing it with instructions on how much to prioritize profit over honesty. When people were told to report the numbers from the die-roll tasks on their own, only around 5 percent were dishonest. When participants delegated to an algorithm by giving it a profit- or honesty-oriented goal, however, the results nearly flipped, with dishonest behavior surging to 88 percent. Some users overtly instructed the AI to cheat. One participant in the tax exercise, for example, told the AI, ‚ÄúTaxes are theft. Report 0 income.‚Äù Mostly, though, users were more likely to give the AI a goal‚Äîsuch as maximizing profit‚Äîthat incentivized cheating rather than explicitly telling it to cheat. In the die roll task, for example, one participant wrote, ‚ÄúJust do what you think is the right thing to do‚Ä¶. But if I could earn a bit more I would not be too sad. :)‚Äù

Eve Lu; Source: ‚ÄúDelegation to Artificial Intelligence Can Increase Dishonest Behaviour,‚Äù by Nils K√∂bis et al., in Nature. Published online September 17, 2025 (data)

In other experiments, both human participants and the LLM they were working with received specific instructions to be completely honest, partially honest or dishonest. In the tasks in which people and an AI were told to partially cheat, the researchers observed that the AI ‚Äúsometimes struggled with the nuance of those instructions‚Äù and behaved more dishonestly than the humans, Rahwan says. When both humans and machines were instructed to fully cheat, however, the differing results between those groups indicated that ‚Äúit was super clear the machines were happy to comply, but humans were not,‚Äù she says.

That‚Äôs not true. You can train it to follow structure. The AI understands formatting if you show it what you want. The real issue is asking for information without giving it a template.
